intro: Hosackia veatchii, commonly known as Veatch's false indigo, is a flowering plant native to the central and southeastern United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and showy violet-blue flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in open woods or along streambanks. It is a perennial herb that produces small, pod-like fruits containing several seeds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
